Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Dynamics and Bifurcations of Human Posture on Tunable Balance Boards

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to study the dynamics of human posture on a balance board with tunable stiffness and time delay and exploit this understanding to improve the early detection of neuromuscular disease and the rehabilitation of balance compromised populations. The research will develop new mathematical models of human posture coupled to an external system and study the emergent dynamics therein; and develop a novel balance board with tunable board rotational stiffness and time delay. This tunable device will be used to assess the potential advantages of bifurcation-based approaches for the early detection of neuromuscular disorder and improved rehabilitation of younger subjects, older subjects and individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS), in collaboration with the Indiana University School of Medicine. In addition an inter-generational service-learning program focused on improving balance will be developed at a local retirement home, a campus wide forum/seminar series on dynamical systems in perception, cognition, and motor control will be created, senior undergraduate students will be mentored in research projects, and the team will reach out to local MS support groups.

The development of the tunable balance board could be a major improvement in rehabilitative devices as it can manipulate and thus, explore the contribution of muscle stiffness and time delay to balance. If successful the idea of using bifurcation thresholds on the tunable balance boards as a means of indicating early stage neuromuscular disease could lead to early diagnosis of fall-propensity in frail older adults and adults with MS, Parkinson?s disease or persons suffering from traumatic brain injury. New detection and training concepts using these tunable balance boards delay could eventually be commercialized and improve quality of life of balance-compromised individuals. In addition, the substantial economic cost associated with falls, valued at over $19 billion in direct medical costs in 2000, may be reduced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Falls and fall-related injuries are pervasive and debilitating in older adults and in those with neuromuscular diseases. Falls result in reduced quality of life, loss of independence, and carry a substantial financial burden to the individual and to society. Balance rehabilitation tools that detect impaired neuromuscular systems and provide interventions are essential given the aging population.

Passive balance boards are frequently used by therapists to improve balance; however, these boards cannot be used to identify neuromuscular disorders and the properties of the balance board cannot be adjusted to optimize rehabilitation for the individual patient. Thus it is important to develop active balance boards – with adjustable parameters – that can be used to identify disorders and also provide optimized treatment of balance impairments. How the person interacts with the balance board as the board changes parameters over time is especially insightful regarding balance. The primary goals of this research were to 1) develop an active balance board with controllable stiffness and time delay that will allow us to understand the underlying mechanisms that result in postural instability, 2) develop mathematical models that reveal the role of the motor and sensory systems in balance control, and 3) detect neuromuscular disorders with better sensitivity than existing methods and develop new rehabilitation protocols to improve balance.

Intellectual Merit

An active balance board with controllable stiffness and time delay was designed, fabricated, and used in experimental studies with young healthy adults and balance-impaired adults. Mathematical models were developed and applied to create a stability plot for each individual tested; the stability plot allowed us to identify the mechanism associated with instability, such as sensory time delay or standing too rigidly. The stability plots were also used to identify the type of instability observed, either tipping or large oscillatory sway patterns – called limit cycle oscillations.

In experimental studies with young adults, the active balance board parameters were adjusted so that the young adults experienced changes that would be observed in a balance-compromised population, such as decreased strength or impaired sensory feedback. These studies revealed that there were sudden changes in a person’s stability with a slow, continuous changes in board parameters. The type of instability (e.g. tipping, oscillatory behavior) was affected by the board parameters, providing deeper insight into the mechanisms of postural stability associated with strength and sensory changes.

The active balance board was used to compare the stability of young adults versus healthy older adults, in order to identify the role of healthy aging (i.e. without disease) in postural instability. The largest difference between young and older adults occurred when the active balance board had the longest time delays and the highest gain. This observation reveals that the greatest sensitivity in the detection of age-related changes occurred in the most difficult balance board settings. Furthermore, the older adults chose a strategy that was more rigid to maintain upright stance, while the young adults appeared to be exploring the task by allowing their posture to change as needed in order to remain upright. These different strategies suggest that modifying the balance board parameters in a manner that induces exploration in older adults is a potential rehabilitative protocol.

Finally, a series of experimental studies with balance-impaired adults were completed. The associated disorders examined were quite broad, including 1) the chronic, progressive diseases of multiple sclerosis and Parkinson’s disease, and 2) the acute, transient instability experienced by concussed athletes (college-aged). The analyses based on the mathematical models revealed that the balance-impaired groups demonstrated limit cycle oscillations in their postural sway that were not evident with visual observation. Since these oscillations were not present in the age-matched control groups, the oscillations likely indicate impaired sensory systems, specifically increased time to detect a change in balance. Furthermore, after recovery, the concussed athletes no longer displayed the oscillatory cycles. Thus, these models and analyses have promise for early detection of diseases and disorders that impair balance.

Broader Impact

The active balance board and associated models have the ability to objectively identify instabilities, identify the underlying mechanisms of the instabilities, detect neuromuscular disorders, and provide individualized rehabilitation to prevent future falls. Improved balance and prevention of falls have the potential to significantly improve quality of life and prolong independence in an aging population. From a clinical perspective, the active balance board will reduce the time necessary for assessment, allowing the therapist more time to focus on rehabilitation. In the future, a large population of multiple age groups will be assessed with the active balance board to identify stability plots of age-matched norms that will provide a benchmark comparison for individuals. Future intervention studies will use these stability plots to identify the rehabilitation approach that is most effective and most efficient, in order to increase adherence (as the patient notices rapid improvement) and reduce training time and associated therapeutic costs.
